column1: In every part of the earth man's first struggle was for his daily food. With only a rude implement of stone or bone he had to get fish from the sea
column3: beast from the forest. For ages
column5: he had to wring a precarious livelihood from nature. He saw
column7: every living form around him similarly trying to satisfy its hunger. There seemed to be a Spirit of Hunger abroad. And
column9: there was such a resistance to man's satisfaction of his need—the bird and fish so hard to get
column10: the stingy earth so ready to give him a stone when he asked for bread—that he came to the conclusion that there must be invisible voracious beings who wanted all good things for themselves. So the ancient world was haunted by a vast brood of Hunger-demons.
